sentence.text: The dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia is based on the transcription elongation from RNA polymerase II promoter that all common treatments involve antidopaminergic mechanisms and genes such as adenylate cyclase-inhibiting dopamine receptor signaling pathway, G protein-coupled receptor internalization, negative regulation of phosphoprotein phosphatase activity, synapse assembly or catecholamine catabolic process are closely related to dopaminergic system functioning.

entity.text: transcription elongation from RNA polymerase II promoter
adenylate cyclase-inhibiting dopamine receptor signaling pathway
negative regulation of phosphoprotein phosphatase activity

sentence.text: The glutamatergic hypothesis of schizophrenia lead recently to a first successful mGlu2/3 receptor agonistic drug and is underpinned by significant findings in genes regulating the glutamatergic system (neurotransmitter uptake, L-glutamate transmembrane transport neuron projection development, response to ethanol, ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport, ventricular trabecula myocardium morphogenesis, signal transduction, neuron projection development, DAAO, G72/30, G protein-coupled glutamate receptor signaling pathway).

entity.text: G protein-coupled glutamate receptor signaling pathway
